**Amado Carrillo Fuentes** ([/fuˈɛntəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"); December 17, 1956 – July 4, 1997) was a
[Mexican](/wiki/Mexican_people "Mexican people") [drug lord](/wiki/Drug_lord
"Drug lord") who seized control of the [Juárez
Cartel](/wiki/Ju%C3%A1rez_Cartel "Juárez Cartel") after assassinating his boss
[Rafael Aguilar Guajardo](/wiki/Rafael_Aguilar_Guajardo "Rafael Aguilar
Guajardo").[1][2] Amado Carrillo became known as "_El Señor de Los Cielos_ "
("The Lord of the Skies"), because of the large fleet of jets he used to
transport drugs. He was also known for [laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering
"Money laundering") money via [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia") to finance
his large fleet of airplanes.

He died in July 1997, in a Mexican hospital, after undergoing extensive
[plastic surgery](/wiki/Plastic_surgery "Plastic surgery") to change his
appearance.[3][4][5] In his final days Carrillo was being tracked by Mexican
and U.S. authorities.

## Family relations and
alliances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Family relations and alliances")]

Carrillo was born to Walter Vicente Carrillo Vega and Aurora Fuentes in
Guamuchilito, Navolato, Sinaloa, Mexico. He was the first of seven sons; the
others were: Cipriano, Enrique B., Vicente, José Cruz, Enrique C., and Jorge.
He also had five sisters: María Luisa, Berthila, Flor, Alicia, and Aurora.

These children were the nieces and nephews of [Ernesto Fonseca
Carrillo](/wiki/Ernesto_Fonseca_Carrillo "Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo"), a/k/a
"Don Neto", the [Guadalajara Cartel](/wiki/Guadalajara_Cartel "Guadalajara
Cartel") leader. Amado got his start in the drug business under the tutelage
of his uncle Ernesto and later brought in his brothers, and eventually his son
Vicente José Carrillo Leyva.

Carrillo's father died in April 1986. Carillo's brother, Cipriano Carrillo
Fuentes, died in 1989 under mysterious circumstances.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Career")]

Initially, Carrillo was part of the [Guadalajara
Cartel](/wiki/Guadalajara_Cartel "Guadalajara Cartel"), sent to
[Ojinaga](/wiki/Ojinaga "Ojinaga"), Chihuahua to oversee the
[cocaine](/wiki/Cocaine "Cocaine") shipments of his uncle, [Ernesto Fonseca
Carrillo](/wiki/Ernesto_Fonseca_Carrillo "Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo") ("Don
Neto"), and to learn about border operations from [Pablo Acosta
Villarreal](/wiki/Pablo_Acosta_Villarreal "Pablo Acosta Villarreal") ("El
Zorro de Ojinaga"; "The Ojinaga Fox") and [Rafael Aguilar
Guajardo](/wiki/Rafael_Aguilar_Guajardo "Rafael Aguilar Guajardo"). Later
Carrillo worked with [Pablo Escobar](/wiki/Pablo_Escobar "Pablo Escobar") and
the [Cali Cartel](/wiki/Cali_Cartel "Cali Cartel") smuggling drugs from
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia") to [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") and
the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). He worked with [El
Chapo](/wiki/El_Chapo "El Chapo") Joaquin Guzman Loera, The [Arellano
Felix](/wiki/Arellano_Felix "Arellano Felix") family and The [Beltran
Leyva](/wiki/Beltran_Leyva "Beltran Leyva") Organization.[6][7] During his
tenure, Carrillo reportedly built a multibillion-dollar drug empire. It was
estimated that he may have made over US$25 billion in revenue in his
career.[8]

##
Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Death")]

The pressure to capture Carrillo intensified among U.S. and Mexican
authorities,[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and
numbers")_][_[why?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please
clarify")_] and perhaps for this reason, Carrillo underwent facial [plastic
surgery](/wiki/Plastic_surgery "Plastic surgery") and abdominal
[liposuction](/wiki/Liposuction "Liposuction") to change his appearance on
July 4, 1997, at Santa Mónica Hospital in [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City
"Mexico City"). However, during the operation, he died of complications
apparently caused either by a medication or a malfunctioning respirator. Two
of Carrillo's bodyguards were in the operating room during the procedure. On
November 7, 1997, the two physicians who performed the surgery on Fuentes were
found dead, encased in concrete inside steel drums, with their bodies showing
signs of torture.[9]

## Juárez Cartel after
Carrillo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Juárez Cartel after Carrillo")]

On the night of August 3, 1997, at around 9:30 p.m., four drug traffickers
walked into a restaurant in [Ciudad Juárez](/wiki/Ciudad_Ju%C3%A1rez "Ciudad
Juárez"), pulled out their guns, and opened fire on five diners, killing them
instantly.[10] Police estimated that more than 100 bullet casings were found
at the crime scene. According to a report issued by the _[Los Angeles
Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ , four men went to the
restaurant carrying at least two [AK-47](/wiki/AK-47 "AK-47") assault rifles
while others stood at the doorstep.[10][11] On their way out, the gunmen
claimed another victim:[12] Armando Olague, a prison official and off-duty law
enforcement officer, who was gunned down outside the restaurant after he had
walked from a nearby bar to investigate the shooting. Reportedly, Olague had
run into the restaurant from across the street with a gun in his hand to check
out the commotion. It was later determined that Olague was also a known
lieutenant of the Juarez cartel.[12] Mexican authorities declined to comment
on the motives behind the killing, stating the shootout was not linked to the
death of Amado Carrillo Fuentes. Nonetheless, it was later stated that the
perpetrators were gunmen of the [Tijuana Cartel](/wiki/Tijuana_Cartel "Tijuana
Cartel").[10][13] Although confrontations between _narcotraficantes_ were
commonplace in Ciudad Juárez, they rarely occurred in public places. What
happened in the restaurant threatened to usher in a new era of border crime in
the city.[12]

In Ciudad Juárez, the PGR seized warehouses they believed the cartel used to
store weapons and cocaine; they also seized over 60 properties all over Mexico
belonging to Carrillo, and began an investigation into his dealings with
police and government officials. Officials also froze bank accounts amounting
to $10 billion belonging to Carrillo.[14] In April 2009, Mexican authorities
arrested Carillo's son, [Vicente Carrillo Leyva](/wiki/Vicente_Carrillo_Leyva
"Vicente Carrillo Leyva").[15]

##
Funeral[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Funeral")]

Carrillo was given a large and expensive funeral in Guamuchilito, Sinaloa. In
2006, [Governor](/wiki/Governor_of_Sonora "Governor of Sonora") [Eduardo
Bours](/wiki/Eduardo_Bours "Eduardo Bours") asked the federal government to
tear down Carrillo's mansion in [Hermosillo](/wiki/Hermosillo "Hermosillo"),
[Sonora](/wiki/Sonora "Sonora").[16] The mansion, dubbed "The Palace of a
Thousand and One Nights", although still standing, remains
unoccupied.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Media
portrayals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amado_Carrillo_Fuentes&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Media portrayals")]

  * In _[El Chapo](/wiki/El_Chapo_\(TV_series\) "El Chapo \(TV series\)")_ , the 2017 [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix") and [Univision](/wiki/Univision "Univision") TV series about the life of [Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán](/wiki/Joaqu%C3%ADn_Guzm%C3%A1n "Joaquín Guzmán"), Fuentes is portrayed by [Rodrigo Abed](/wiki/Rodrigo_Abed "Rodrigo Abed").
  * _[El Señor de los Cielos](/wiki/El_Se%C3%B1or_de_los_Cielos "El Señor de los Cielos")_ (2013), _[El Señor de los Cielos 2](/wiki/El_Se%C3%B1or_de_los_Cielos#Season_2_\(2014\) "El Señor de los Cielos")_ (2014), _El Señor de los Cielos 3_ (2015), and _El Señor de los Cielos 4_ , aired as part of [Telemundo](/wiki/Telemundo "Telemundo")'s nighttime programming, stars the Mexican actor [Rafael Amaya](/wiki/Rafael_Amaya "Rafael Amaya") as Aurelio Casillas (a fictionalized version of Amado Carrillo Fuentes).[17]
  * In the [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix") Original series _[Narcos](/wiki/Narcos "Narcos"),_ Fuentes is portrayed by [José María Yazpik](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Yazpik "José María Yazpik").
